title: Stock Futures Slip to Kick Off August Trading; Some traders are now expecting the Federal Reserve to raise rates more slowly, sparking a decline in the U.S. dollar
text:
U.S. stocks mounted a furious recovery in recent weeks, boosted by positive signals from earnings and expectations that the Federal Reserve may not need to raise interest rates as aggressively as once thought.

Last week, officials approved another unusually large interest-rate increase, lifting their federal-funds rate to a range between 2.25% and 2.5%. But traders are now betting that the size of rate increases will shrink for the rest of the year.

Investors have remained cautious amid decades-high inflation, the war in Ukraine and expectations that the U.S. economy will slip into a recession. Some expect remarks from central bank officials in the next few weeks to heavily sway markets, especially as thin summer trading volumes extend into August.

On Sunday, Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis President Neel Kashkari said on CBS's "Face the Nation" that inflation remains "very concerning" and that central bankers would do what's needed to bring price pressures down.

"This has been a very rapid repricing of bond and equity markets," said Edward Park, chief investment officer at U.K. investment firm Brooks Macdonald. "I think the pivot might be premature."

Mr. Park noted that Monday's weakness in stock futures suggested investors are likely taking a breather after the S&P 500 finished Friday with a 9.1% gain for July. He added that traders are in "wait and see" mode ahead of Friday's jobs report.

Investors' expectations for a less aggressive Fed have been evident in federal-funds futures, which are used by traders to place bets on the course of interest rates. Such futures on Monday morning showed a nearly 71% probability that the Fed will raise its key interest rate by 0.5 percentage point in September, up from just 44% last week.

Investors' shifting expectations for central-bank policy for the rest of the year have scrambled other areas of financial markets in recent days, upending some trades that have flourished this year. The U.S. dollar, for example, whichhas staged a prolonged rise in 2022, fell on Monday for a fourth consecutive session, with the WSJ Dollar Index losing 0.5%.

The Japanese yen, meanwhile, advanced again, rising 1% against the dollar. The yen's recent rise has challenged a popular trade on Wall Street this year: betting against the Japanese currency.

In the bond market, the yield on the 10-year U.S. Treasury note traded at 2.665%, up from 2.642% Friday. The yield on the benchmark note has come down significantly from its closing high of 3.482% reached in June.

The yield on the two-year Treasury note, meanwhile, traded at 2.907%, up from 2.897% Friday, to keep the so-called yield curve inverted. That market signal, which occurs when short-term Treasury yields trade higher than long-term yields, is often seen as a key predictor of a recession.

In premarket trading in New York, shares of Boeing rose 3.2% after the plane maker temporarily avoided a strike at three defense manufacturing plants.

Later Monday, investors will parse earnings from companies including Diamondback Energy, Pinterest and Activision Blizzard, all of which will report after the closing bell.

In energy markets, Brent crude ticked down 1.2% to $102.68 a barrel.

Overseas, the pan-continental Stoxx Europe 600 rose 0.2%. London-traded shares of HSBC Holdings rose 5.9% after the global banking giant said profit rose 62% in the second quarter from a year earlier.

In Asia, indexes traded mostly higher, despite data showing Chinese manufacturing activity unexpectedly contracted in July. Hong Kong's Hang Seng gained 0.1%, while China's Shanghai Composite rose 0.2%. Japan's Nikkei 225 jumped 0.7%.
